head.title: For Some, the Boys of Summer Never Left

abstract.p: Ed Grimm letter on his fond memories of Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field

Re ''Ebbets Lights Dimmed Again'' (news article, Sept. 27):

Those vanished ballparks, Ebbets Field and the Polo Grounds, still exist for those of us who pushed through their turnstiles to savor the special excitement of the Dodgers-Giants interborough rivalry.

As a boy growing up in Washington Heights, I could walk to the Polo Grounds, where I would sit in the bleachers for an all-encompassing view of the playing field and a closeup view of the peerless Willie Mays in center field. But, because I was a Dodger fan, it was Ebbets Field that claimed my heart.

Everything about the place -- the Brooklyn Sym-Phony that serenaded umpires with ''Three Blind Mice,'' the right-field sign of the clothier Abe Stark that challenged batters to ''Hit Sign Win Suit,'' Hilda Chester and her cow bell, Red Barber in the broadcasting booth -- was warm and inviting and, well, different. And the players and the games . . . ah, memories of them will never yield to time's wrecking ball.
